title.narrative: OUTPUT 3.1 ADO: QUALITY HEALTHCARE, NUTRITION, Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH)

description.narrative: 3.1 By 2022, the health and nutrition service delivery systems provide quality healthcare, nutrition and Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) interventions for adolescent girls and boys, especially the most deprived, which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women, Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Communications, Advocacy And Public Engagement, Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Data, Research, Evaluation And Knowledge Management, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, adolescent boys and girls, especially the most deprived, live free from violence, have capability to reach their full potential and contribute to a cohesive and resilient society.

participating-org.narrative: DEPARTMENT OF NATIONAL COMMUNITY WATER SUPPLY

sector.narrative: Overall WASH – systems strengthening (e.g. sector-wide coordination, enabling environment and financing advocacy)
Sanitation and hygiene - institutions (schools, health care facilities, ECD centres) including menstrual hygiene management
Strengthening data and national information systems, including routine systems, nutrition surveys and assessments (nutrition of school-age children, adolescents and women)
Technical Assistance - Nutrition of adolescents and women
Water sector policy and administrative management
Water supply and sanitation - large systems

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: 3.1 By 2022, the health and nutrition service delivery systems provide quality healthcare, nutrition and WASH interventions foradolescent girls and boys, especially the most deprived

description.narrative: Initial steps were taken to include WASH indicators into the education and health information management systems through sustained advocacy and technical discussions. At the school level, WASH indicators were identified, together with the Ministry of Education, for inclusion in the upcoming school census and integrated into the Education Information Management System (EMIS). In health care facilities, agreement was reached to conduct a WASH assessment which will collect relevant information to update the WASH status in health care facilities; an important first step in addressing critical gaps.;; | Status:Met | As-of Date:02/02/2022

title.narrative: Availability of baseline information on WASH in health care facilities (SDG indicators 6.1 and 6.2) as part of the Health Information Management System (HMIS)(66677), Text

baseline.value: Score 1: No baseline data available on WASH in health care facilities (SDG indicators 6.1 and 6.2)

target.value: 2022:Score 3 (The national protocols for the management of SAM based on WHO standards (2013) have been drafted.)

actual.value: 2021:Score 02 The Ministry of Health was trained to design a WASH survey in health care facilities. A technical working group was established to implement the Survey in 2022. Core questions were developed for the EMIS and advocated to be included in the sch

title.narrative: Availability of a comprehensive package of teaching/learning materials for school administrators and teachers on Menstrual Hygiene Management in schools(66676), Text

baseline.value: Score 1: There is a lack of a comprehsive training package and training programmes for teachers and school administrators on Menstrual Hygiene Management in schools.

target.value: 2022:Score 3 (The national protocols for the management of SAM based on WHO standards (2013) have been drafted.)

actual.value: 2021:Score 2 The drafts of teacher training materials and student self-learning materials on MHM are available. The training package will be finalized in 2022.
